comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: In flight picture of Douglas AD-3W / AD-3E Skyraider. In Gloss 'Sea Blue' overall with large national insignia as applied to US Navy aircraft prior to 1955. Navy serial number on rear lower fuselage may be interpreted as 122906 which is within known AD-3W serial batch sequence. Squadron code XA of test squadron VX-1 with side number 6 repeated on top of wing. www.vaq34.com/vxe6/vxtailcode.htm Professor Joe Baugher of Chicago Illinois provides excellent type by type info on the Douglas AD/A-1 Skyraider & AD-3W: www.joebaugher.com/usattack/newa1.html www.joebaugher.com/usattack/newa1_10.html The AD-3W was an early warning version of the AD-3 with a large AN/APS-20 search radar in a radome underneath the fuselage and extended fairing aft of cockpit with extra vertical finlets on horizontal stabilizer. The giant radome underneath the fuselage made the AD-3W bulkier and less maneuverable than other Skyraiders. 31 were built. Info on VX-1 (code XA) Air Development Squadron One While based at Boca Chica Field, NAS Key West, Florida. vx-1.ahf.nmci.navy.mil/history.htm www.vpnavy.org/vx1_aircraft.html Picture of AD-3W Bu No 122906 as Modex 6 of VX-1 in company with an AD-3N: commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:AD-3E_AD-3S_VX-1_NAN7-70.jpg A Douglas AD-3E (BuNo 122906) and an AD-3S Skyraider of U.S. Navy experimental squadron VX-1 in flight, about 1950. Two AD-3Ws (BuNos 122906 and 122907) and two AD-3Ns (BuNos 122901 and 122911) were modified as AD-3E (search) and AD-3S (attack) aircraft in an experimental program to demonstrate the feasibility of hunter/killer antisubmarine teams. Under this strategy, the AD-3E and AD-3S would operate in pairs, with the AD-3E hunting for submarines, and the AD-3S destroying the submarine once it was found. Picture dated 1950. Taken from U.S. Navy Naval Aviation News July 1970 issue. A copy of the above ‘flickr’ pic may also be viewed in this downloadable PDF: books.google.co.uk/books?id=qCjavscsWXMC&pg=PA24&... “The ships and aircraft of the United States Fleet” By James Charles Fahey Thus the aircraft in the ‘flickr’ pic is identified as AD-3E Bu No 122906, modified from an AD-3W.
